2.48.text:
If it’s not already clear, my focus tonight
is to talk about the Spartans and I think

6.83.text:
it’s not a stretch of the imagination to
say that most people when they encounter the

10.81.text:
Spartans, encounter them via some format involving
the Battle of Thermopylae. In some ways I

17.15.text:
would say that the famous last stand of Leonidas
at Thermopylae is synonymous with Sparta and

23.91.text:
you can sort of see that in the nice obvious
popular culture reference I have on the screen

27.27.text:
here for you. I don’t know why I’m pointing
at that screen, I should be pointing at that

29.65.text:
screen because there’s screens at the back
where I can see what I’m talking about as

35.12.text:
The older generation might have encountered
the Battle of Thermopylae in the 1962 film

41.05.text:
‘The 300 Spartans’; they might have encountered
it in William Golding’s 1965 collection

46.54.text:
of essays entitled ‘The Hot Gates’; they
might have encountered it in a variety of

50.87.text:
different ways. You might have encountered
the Spartans as I did at high school when

54.08.text:
I was 12 years old and I’ve been interested
in working on them ever since. But the odd

59.45.text:
thing about it is Leonidas and his 300, or
the remnant of the 300 who fought and died

64.89.text:
on the last day at Thermopylae would never
have realised or expected that any of their

70.29.text:
actions would have actually led to us talking
about the Spartans today. According to Herodotus,

76.28.text:
when Leonidas and his men realised that they
had been surrounded and that they would die

81.72.text:
if they remained on the field of battle, they
remained there not out of any great desire

86.78.text:
to generate fame, not so that they would have
a spectacular death, but because they deemed

93.42.text:
it would be unseemly not to remain at their
post. It was unseemly because the Spartan

99.92.text:
way to do things was to remain at your post
no matter what and that’s something that

104.99.text:
becomes very clear in Simonides famous epigram
written for the Spartans after the event which

110.45.text:
you can see a modern version of at the site
of the Battle of Thermopylae today and the

115.28.text:
translation of it is “Oh stranger, tell
the Spartans that we lie here, obedient to

120.02.text:
their words”. This is often translated as
‘obedient do their laws’ but literally

125.48.text:
it just says the things that they have said.
So they died at Thermopylae because of their

133.12.text:
obedience to what Spartans told them to do.
So the much heralded obedience is what I want

139.78.text:
to focus on tonight, but to put things into
perspective quickly for those of you who are

143.57.text:
not entirely familiar with the Spartans, I’ve
got a few slides to sort tell a little bit

148.88.text:
of story so that we can get some background
in before we get onto the much bigger, meatier,

154.92.text:
So for those of you who are unfamiliar with
the Spartans, they can be found in the town

158.88.text:
of Sparta here, they were relative incomers
into the Greek world, migrants from somewhere

165.49.text:
north of Greece, entered into that area in
the 9th or 8th centuries BC, quickly conquered

171.82.text:
the surrounding territory, somewhat enslaved,
somewhat of the local inhabitants, having

178.21.text:
made a success of that they crossed the mountains
and conquered their neighbouring people next

182.64.text:
door, the Messenians. The conquest and enslavement
of those people enabled them to devote themselves

189.64.text:
to the warrior lifestyle that we then see
in action at the Battle of Thermopylae. It

195.62.text:
allowed them to call themselves a society
of equals. The term they used for themselves

200.71.text:
was the ‘homoioi’ which we translate sometimes
as ‘peers’, sometimes as ‘equals’,

205.08.text:
sometimes as ‘similars’. The other term
for citizens is the ‘Spartiates’. They

211.02.text:
emphasised their equality by having the same
appearance. They had their hair long, they

217.21.text:
wore red cloaks. In the early phase of what
I’m talking about today they had long red

222.66.text:
cloaks, later on they had shorter red cloaks,
but they dressed the same, they looked the

227.64.text:
same. They pretended that they were equal
in terms of wealth but it’s very much a

233.18.text:
pretence; there were much wealthier Spartans
but the wealth was masked as Anton Powell

238.30.text:
puts it, the Spartans were very good at lying
not just to outsiders but to themselves as

243.02.text: well about how this society actually worked.

245.90.text:
I’ve got some other nice images of Spartans
to put things in perspective as well so we

250.81.text:
can get away from the popular image of the
Spartans in the film ‘300’ and things

255.48.text:
like that. I have a nice vase painting which
is probably meant to relate to the Persian

260.31.text:
wars. You have a very long-haired Spartan
there, fighting stark naked. There is no evidence

265.88.text:
that Spartans fought stark naked but there
are lots of vase paintings showing this and

270.69.text:
this is clearly a popular image. There’s
a classical period scaraboid showing what

276.35.text:
is obviously a Spartan fighting against a
Persian here and despite what you think the

282.54.text:
Spartans might look like from the film ‘300’
with the big Corinthian style helmet that

286.48.text:
covers their face, they’re much more likely
to have a helmet like this one here which

290.53.text:
is sort of like a London bobby’s helmet
rather than what you see in films.

295.59.text:
So to take things back to the Battle of Thermopylae,
take things back to obedience, I start with

300.58.text:
Passage 1 on your epic handout if you’ve
got your handout, and I think Michael’s

306.05.text:
missed out on one so unfortunately I need
the one I have because I’m going to return

310.08.text:
to it frequently. Prior to the battle at Thermopylae,
Xerxes the Persian King, sent spies to see

319.29.text:
what the Greeks were doing because he realised
that Greeks were trying to stop him at the

323.92.text:
narrow pass at Thermopylae and he was slightly
baffled by this because according to Herodotus

329.44.text:
he had millions of men. He will have had hundreds
of thousands of men, or maybe 150,000 men,

334.44.text:
and there were only 4,000 Greeks trying to
stop him. When he learned from the spy that

340.26.text:
the Spartans were exercising naked and combing
their hair he was slightly baffled by this,

345.63.text:
so he summoned one of his entourage, a man
by the name of Demaratus who was an exiled

349.99.text:
Spartan King and said ‘what are these weird
people doing?’ and Demaratus explained that

354.97.text:
that’s what Spartans do when they’re preparing
themselves to die. Xerxes couldn’t understand

360.49.text:
this because he couldn’t understand why
so few men would actually fight against his

364.93.text:
massive army and Demaratus went on to explain
to him that it’s because of their obedience.

372.71.text:
He says that the Spartans ‘are the bravest
soldiers and fighting together they are the

377.62.text:
best on earth’ and he goes on to say that
‘this is because they are free, yet not

381.96.text:
wholly free, because law - ‘nomos’ is
the Greek word here – is their master whom

387.15.text:
they fear much more than your men fear you.
They do whatever it bids and its bidding is

392.17.text:
always the same, that they must never flee
from the battle before any multitude of men

396.81.text:
but must abide by their post and there conquer
or die’. So the Spartans are going to fight

403.44.text:
against Xerxes because of their resolute,
not just obedience to the law but their fear

409.97.text:
of the law that makes them what you might
want to think of as ‘super obedient’.

414.43.text:
We then get a series of images of resolute
Spartans from Herodotus as well that put that

420.87.text:
in perspective and I’ve got an image of
arrowheads from the battlefield at Thermopylae

425.43.text:
to put this in perspective for you. Herodotus
tells us that when someone tried to scare

429.79.text:
the Spartans and tell them that there were
so many Persian archers that their arrows

434.97.text:
would make the sky go dark, one of the Spartans
responded ‘well that’s a good thing, we’ll

438.54.text:
fight in the shade’ and perhaps the most
iconic response of the Spartans doesn’t

443.12.text:
come from Herodotus, it comes from a much
later source, is the claim that Leonidas when

447.97.text:
Xerxes demanded the Spartans’ handover their
arms responded in two words, ‘come and take

453.45.text:
them’. It’s an image that has left its
mark on our society today and there’s a

458.92.text:
wonderful – I say wonderful – poster from
the NRA to put that in perspective there,

463.50.text:
the way they have taken on this image of the
resolute response of the Spartans to ask them

472.46.text:
So what we have here is a series of images
of bravery being equated with obedience at

478.76.text:
Sparta and they’re not isolated episodes.
There are frequent references to Spartan obedience

483.97.text:
in our sources and I’ve got a few of them
in your epic handout here. So you have in

491.00.text:
number 2, you’ll have from Thucydides’
History of the Peloponnesian War, you have

495.84.text:
the Spartan King Archidamus talking to his
fellow citizens about why they are going to

501.12.text:
win against the Athenians and he says they
need to think about how powerful the Athenians

506.51.text:
are but remember that they are going to win
because they follow where they will be led,

514.99.text:
they regard discipline and vigilance as of
first importance and to obey with alacrity

519.70.text:
the orders transmitted to each other. He said
‘this is what is going to make us defeat

524.47.text:
the Athenians’. In passage 3, he has another
attempt to inspire the Spartans to fight against

530.27.text:
the Athenians, making it clear again that
obedience to the law is the most important

536.05.text:
part of their method in terms of approaching
warfare. It says ‘we are war-like because

542.49.text:
self-control contains honour as a chief constituent
and we honour bravery. We are wise because

549.55.text:
we are educated with too little learning to
despise the laws and with too severe a self-control

557.90.text:
to disobey them’. It goes on to say that
they will be prepared for any eventuality

563.95.text:
that comes against them and this is what separates
them from everyone else. Their superiority

569.96.text:
lies with them being read in the severest
school. In passage 4 you have Plutarch highlighting

579.66.text:
Spartan obedience again. He says ‘if any
Spartan was summoned to see the Spartan officials,

584.46.text:
the ephors, he did not walk slowly in obeying
the summons but by running eagerly at full

589.82.text:
speed through the marketplace. They exhibited
to their fellow citizens their spirit of obedience,

595.72.text:
rejoicing in paying homage to their rulers’.
And probably my favourite one of these passages

601.83.text:
here, number 5, is the Spartan general Brasidas
speaking to his second in command. He tells

607.91.text:
him to ‘show himself a brave man, as a Spartan
should’ and then goes on to talk to the

612.46.text:
allies and says ‘follow him and remember
that zeal, honour and obedience mark the good

618.49.text:
soldier and this day will make you either
free men or slaves of the Athenians and he

623.99.text:
will go on to show that he can practice what
he preaches as well’. So it makes it very

628.48.text:
clear that obedience is the important factor
here.

633.22.text:
You have one other example of obedience that
I want to talk about and I’ve got a modern

637.24.text:
artwork to put this in perspective. In the
middle of the 6th century there’s a battle

642.43.text:
which is known to us as the Battle of the
Champions which makes it sound like some sort

647.21.text:
of gameshow. The Spartans disputed a territory,
adjacent territory, with their neighbouring

654.18.text:
enemies, the Argives. The two city states
decided rather than have a major pitched battel

662.10.text:
they would pick 300 champions who would fight
to the death to decide who got to keep the

668.07.text:
disputed territory. At the end of the battle,
two Argives survived and they promptly went

673.26.text:
back to their army to tell the Argives that
they had won. There was one surviving Spartan

679.09.text:
by the name of Othryades; he decided to stay
on the field of battle, he stripped the corpses

684.99.text:
of the Argives of their armour, set up a battlefield
trophy and the Spartans then were able to

690.62.text:
argue that they had in fact won. They ended
up having a major battle afterwards in which

695.89.text:
there were huge numbers of casualties. The
Spartans won, they kept the disputed territory

700.52.text:
and Othryades then committed suicide because
he thought that it was shameful that he had

705.29.text:
survived when all of his fellow champions
had died. It gets turned into a wonderful

711.59.text:
example of Spartan over the top behaviour
later on. Plutarch describes Othryades having

719.37.text:
written an inscription, or a message, about
the victory in the Battle of Champions, in

726.63.text:
his own blood as he committed suicide. So
you’ve got this message very strongly that

732.18.text:
this is the kind of thing that Spartans do.
And I’ve got one more negative example to

736.87.text:
bring up before I get into the bigger issues
as well and that’s the fate of the survivor

743.18.text:
of the Battle of Thermopylae, a man by the
name of Aristodemus who survived the battle

748.23.text:
because he had what Herodotus calls ‘an
affliction of the eye’. He came home rather

754.44.text:
than fight to the death. When he got back
he was derided as a coward. The Spartans had

761.08.text:
a word for coward which was a ‘trembler’.
He was known as Aristodemus the Trembler and

766.02.text:
he was shunned by everyone and ultimately
he would go on to commit suicide at the subsequent

773.04.text:
Battle of Plataea in spectacular style, but
the Spartans were not impressed by his show

780.25.text:
of bravery as the rest of the Greeks saw it.
Their response was ‘well he wanted to die

785.10.text: so it wasn’t brave at all’.

788.27.text:
So there’s some sort of stereotypes about
the Spartans and when you go back and look

793.39.text:
at secondary scholarship, particularly things
written in the early part of the 20th century,

797.57.text:
all of these stories about the Spartans tended
to be accepted at face value and Spartan society

804.03.text:
was seen as a society that decided one day
to turn itself into a brutal militaristic

810.16.text:
regime and I have an image from Larry Gonick’s
Cartoon History of the Universe to put this

814.16.text:
in perspective here where you have a Spartan
ploughing a field saying ‘no, I don’t

817.45.text:
want to do this anymore, I want someone else
to do it’ and that this is the idea that

821.03.text:
the Spartans then decided that they would
just conquer the Messenians and turn themselves

825.69.text:
into this militarised society. And it’s
something that the other Greeks believed happened

831.02.text:
as well and Thucydides who probably ought
to have known better in their early part of

835.83.text:
his history of the Peloponnesian War, describes
Sparta as having had the same constitution

840.32.text:
for more than four hundred years and that
is clearly not the case but this is the message

845.18.text:
the Spartans managed to produce that the rest
of the Greeks understood and they themselves

849.78.text:
probably swallowed a little bit as well. So
the Spartans are often seen as a society that

857.21.text:
destroyed themselves, or have often been seen
that way. It’s a society that destroyed

861.66.text:
themselves by trying to retain control of
Mycenaea and the helots who they conquered.

869.09.text:
People would pay a lot of attention to Thucydides
wonderful statement that ‘most Spartan institutions

874.40.text:
had been designed with a view to security
against the helots’. So the Spartans had

878.92.text:
been compared to the Legend of Fafner and
turned himself into a dragon to protect the

883.79.text:
gold that he had and then couldn’t enjoy
it. So the Spartans are seen in the same way.

888.61.text:
They’ve conquered this territory, they now
have a life of freedom, except they then have

893.06.text:
to spend all their time becoming professional
soldiers who will be brave and obedient and

898.08.text:
fight to the death. So you also have some
other stereotypes coming out and this is bringing

904.69.text:
in [0:15:04] nicely for you here the idea
that the helots are a simmering mass of resentment

910.64.text:
who will be able to rise up against the Spartans
whenever they like, and in one of the surviving

915.39.text:
fragments of Tyrtaeus’ poetry they’re
described as ‘like donkeys exhausted under

919.60.text:
great loads who was forced to bring the masters
half of the fruits of their land’ and I

923.15.text:
have an image of a donkey from an animal welfare
site to put that in perspective for you, that

928.23.text: this is not a happy lifestyle for the helots.

933.85.text:
But Sparta isn’t quite what the stereotypes
would tell you and since the 1980s there has

939.34.text:
been a surge of work on Sparta and I have
the covers of some volumes here to put that

945.79.text:
in perspective and we heard the talk from
about fifteen years ago – this is not working

951.69.text:
properly – we have Michael’s book on Sparta
there in all its glory, alongside a host of

958.39.text:
volumes dedicated totally to Sparta. There’s
been, I think it’s not unfair to say, an

964.20.text:
explosion of work on Sparta. Increasingly
this work has been looking at challenging

970.05.text:
and debating all the preconceptions we have
about the Spartans. Pretty much everything

975.86.text:
about Sparta has been challenged. An example
of that is the nature of the relationship

980.10.text:
between the Spartans and their helots. It
was frequently, or normally, seen as very

986.09.text:
much a class struggle. The oppressed helots
ready to rise up against the Spartans at any

992.23.text:
point in time. People have started to look
at things in another way and think well maybe

996.74.text:
the relationship between the Spartans and
the helots is a lot more symbiotic. The idea

1001.80.text:
that the Spartans are a militarised society
has been questioned and the notion that the

1007.84.text:
Spartans are exceptional is something that
has been debated as well and that will continue

1012.12.text:
to be debated and explored in the forthcoming
Blackwell Companion to Sparta as well which

1017.16.text:
is coming out later in the year. And one of
the things that’s happened as people have

1022.55.text:
started to reappraise Sparta and what the
Spartans is like is the image of Spartan obedience

1028.91.text:
has come under attack as well. Relatively
recently Jon Hesk and Ellen Millender amongst

1034.59.text:
others have highlighted the fact that the
image of Spartan obedience is coming out very

1039.77.text:
strongly in Athenian sources. So a lot of
those quotations I gave you earlier are sources

1045.29.text:
that are written by Athenians or have a very
strong connection with the Athenians. So what

1050.66.text:
people have started to do was say this image
of Spartan obedience is a negative stereotype

1056.91.text:
and it’s the Athenians telling you a negative
thing about the Spartans. So one of the things

1063.86.text:
that you can focus on here is the Athenians
cast themselves as naturally brave, whereas

1069.36.text:
the Spartans have to have bravery beaten into
them. Another thing that people focus on is

1075.22.text:
the fact that one of the key messages about
Spartan obedience comes from Demaratus who

1081.50.text:
is a rather ambiguous character. He’s exiled
from Sparta, he is a traitor to the Greek

1087.81.text:
cause, he can be viewed as a collaborator.
So if a collaborator is telling you this message

1093.19.text:
about the Spartans, does this dilute his message?
That’s one way of looking at it; I would

1098.32.text:
argue and will be arguing soon that perhaps
the fact that he’s such an ambivalent character,

1104.02.text:
ambiguous character, might highlight the message
that he’s giving you so that even someone

1109.82.text:
as flawed as Demaratus can see how Spartans
are meant to behave.

1114.81.text:
The other thing to think about in this question
also is negative stereotypes. They are not

1119.77.text:
by default untrue and they are not by default
viewed as negative by the people who are being

1127.94.text:
described in a negative kind of way. So just
because the Athenians thought Spartan obedience

1133.88.text:
was a bad thing, doesn’t mean Spartans thought
that obedience was a bad thing. And there

1139.78.text:
are various messages that tell you that they
clearly didn’t think that their obedience

1145.02.text:
was a bad thing and a good example of that
comes from your handout yet again – and

1151.85.text:
I foolishly do not have notes to myself on
this one – number 19, Herodotus tells us

1158.32.text:
that prior to the Battle of Thermopylae, the
Spartans were getting bad omens and they realised

1166.65.text:
this was because they had killed sacred ambassadors
from the Persians and they decided they needed

1175.23.text:
to atone for this. They called for volunteers
and two men by the names of Sperthias and

1180.21.text:
Bulis volunteered themselves to sacrifice
themselves for the Spartan state and they

1185.22.text:
went all the way to meet Xerxes who refused
to kill them, and then they went all the way

1188.97.text:
home again. But the interesting thing is that
along the way they met Hydarnes who was a

1194.73.text:
prominent Persian who would ultimately go
on to fight against them at the Battle of

1198.63.text:
Thermopylae and he told them that they should
go over to Xerxes because they would be received

1204.92.text:
as men of honour. The response of Sperthias
and Bulis was that he was advising them in

1212.94.text:
such a way because he didn’t understand
the reality of life and he had only experienced

1218.28.text:
slavery. Whereas what they had experienced
was freedom and because they had experienced

1224.70.text:
freedom, they were never going to submit to
the Persians. So these are the same Spartans

1230.90.text:
who have the laws as their tyrant. They actually
see themselves as free. What we think was

1238.75.text:
the Spartan citizenship oath said that it
made Spartans swear that they would not put

1244.20.text:
being alive ahead of being free. As far as
they were concerned, they were free. One of

1251.32.text:
the interesting things about Spartan freedom
is in debates in the 18th century about how

1256.57.text:
modern Europe should be governed, Sparta was
sometimes put forward as a role model because

1263.95.text:
of the notion of freedom, not because everyone
was free but because the state itself was

1270.03.text:
free. Now very few people actually sensibly
argued that Sparta was a role model but it

1274.46.text:
was something that people considered. So the
Spartans equate their obedience to the laws

1285.91.text:
So the other thing that’s worth focusing
on at this point in time is that the Spartans

1290.47.text:
seemed to be a society not just that has a
different understanding of the rules compared

1295.23.text:
to the rest of the Greeks, but they’d also
be a society that seems to have set themselves

1301.34.text:
separately from the rest of the Greeks as
well and some of the following images should

1305.85.text:
put that in perspective for you. This is the
fertile valley of Messenia which the Spartans

1312.86.text:
conquered and then enslaved the inhabitants
and basically became absentee landlords of

1318.08.text:
the land. This is the mountain range that
separates the Spartans from their conquests

1323.03.text:
in Messenia. The Taygetus mountain range is
by no means small, approximately 2,500 metres

1330.43.text:
high at its highest, it’s very precipitous,
anyone who’s driven over it will know it

1335.23.text:
is not fun, particularly when it’s snowing.
It effectively cuts the Spartans off from

1339.59.text:
the Messenians but the Spartans are also quite
significantly cut off from the rest of the

1346.81.text:
Peloponnese as well and I’ve got a map here
to sort of put this in perspective. You have

1350.39.text:
the Spartans here and you have the urbanish
area where you will find the Spartans and

1357.33.text:
you’ve got Taygetus mountain range here,
there’s another mountain range down here

1361.42.text:
and the mountains in Arcadia here are quite
impressively difficult to negotiate. So the

1369.09.text:
Spartans are actually quite isolated in terms
of where they are in the Greek world, so I’d

1375.14.text:
sort of think of these mountains as a combination
of physical and metaphorical frontier. The

1381.85.text:
Spartans famously do not have city walls which
makes them quite unusual in the Ancient Greek

1386.30.text:
world and one of the reasons they don’t
have city walls is they don’t really need

1389.86.text:
them because of the combination of military
threat that they offer but also the relative

1395.99.text:
inaccessibility of Sparta and that’s something
that actually is highlighted quite nicely

1401.64.text:
in passage 29, the penultimate passage, where
a fellow Peloponnesian is explaining to the

1412.86.text:
Athenians why the Spartans are in a strong
position and why they are able to be a military

1419.01.text:
threat to them and this is at a point where
Sparta is no longer a very serious military

1422.68.text:
threat and it highlights the fact that they
are shut off from the sea and that they are

1427.77.text:

2856.62.text:

in a positive and a negative way, to the point
where they end up celebrating their injuries

2922.04.text:
as a badge of honour and their commitment
to the institution that they are part of and

2926.63.text:
they spend longer and longer hours in the
institution rather than actually trying to

2930.77.text:
leave it, which is technically allowed to
them. It’s useful for thinking about when

2934.94.text:
we consider how and when the Spartans developed
their unique society and one of the things

2939.12.text:
I’m pondering here is did they effectively
choose to set themselves up that way and then

2944.65.text:
degenerate into what the Goffman would have
recognised as a total institution proper.

2950.38.text:
And if I have time, and I think I have time,
I just want to give a few examples of where

2954.74.text:
Sparta might actually look a total institution
so that we can actually reflect on this a

2963.73.text:
Sparta actually has a lot of aspects to its
society that look like a total institution.

2970.86.text:
There’s the fearsome focus on obedience
to the rules and the need to be seen to follow

2975.61.text:
them. Boys not getting caught is part of the
key message we get from our primary sources

2981.49.text:
and the almost entirely apocryphal story but
a very famous example of the Spartan boy who

2988.28.text:
stole a fox was going to be caught with the
fox, hid it under his cloak to protect his

2994.93.text:
fellow Spartan boys and allowed the fox to
claw him to death rather than admit that he

3002.32.text:
had been stealing. Men are not meant to be
caught entering the quarters of their wives.

3008.94.text:
You’re not meant to be seen breaking the
rules in something that’s very obviously

3013.27.text:
part of Spartan society and it’s something
that is typical of a total institution. There

3022.54.text:
is also a strong emphasis in the Spartan society
of what sociologists call ‘removal activities’

3030.82.text:
- the gymnastic exercises, the brutal ball
games, the choral singing, the dancing, the

3037.74.text:
marching, that takes place in Sparta, the
singing of songs while marching that resembles

3044.61.text:
marching cadences used in the modern military,
the strong emphasis on hunting as well that

3051.08.text:
is part of Spartan society and I have a Spartan
wine cup with a hunting scene on that. It’s

3058.03.text:
not just a removal activity, it’s also something
that the modern military would recognise as

3063.48.text:
well. It is something that is conditioning
Spartans to killing, something that psychologists

3069.15.text:
refer to as ‘conditioning you to tolerate
the gore’ and we have the gore in this image

3074.98.text:
here. You have the blood streaking down the
wounded animals there. One of the things that

3082.50.text:
the modern military has worked out is people
don’t like killing other people. Funny that.

3089.25.text:
They need to be conditioned to do it. Target
practice needs to actually have human like

3094.79.text:
shapes otherwise people won’t actually want
to kill other people and evidence from important

3101.32.text:
battlefields suggests that people are very
scared about killing other people. I can talk

3106.60.text:
about that in questions if we have time later
on. There is a strong use of uniforms in Sparta.

3113.38.text:
They wear their red cloaks, they have their
long hair, boys are issued with a sickle and

3121.18.text:
they will dedicate their sickle after their
graduate into adulthood. The uniforms do not

3128.72.text:
just apply to the Spartans themselves; the
helots are dressed in skins. This is often

3134.53.text:
associated with making them seem more animal
like but the wording to describe the skins

3139.82.text:
that the helots wear is actually just leather.
It’s the type of dress you associate with

3147.05.text:
servile workers elsewhere in the Greek world.
So the helots are the workers, the Spartans

3154.41.text:
have the uniform of the soldiers. Punishment
for failure, if you are a coward in Sparta

3160.36.text:
you don’t get to look like a Spartan. You
have to shave off half of your beards so you

3165.05.text:
look ridiculous. You don’t get to wear the
red cloak after all. This is a photo of a

3169.73.text:
mugshot from an American website – I don’t
know why the man in question decided to make

3174.83.text:
himself look like that. There’s a period
of mortification as you would find in a total

3182.13.text:
institution. The boys have their heads shaved.
There’s a strong focus on dirtiness, they’re

3186.79.text:
not allowed to bathe and this is something
that is recognisable in the worst type of

3192.40.text:
total institution. There is a strong emphasis
on corporal punishment. Those of you who know

3199.21.text:
anything about punishments in the military,
they like to punish people by making them

3203.26.text:
hold up rifles. The Spartans have a punishment
where you have to hold up the huge wooden

3208.88.text:
bronze faced shield. It’s exactly the same
type of punishment. They have to rip the reeds

3216.55.text:
out of the reed bed to make their beds. In
some concentration camps the beds were made

3225.42.text:
out of straw and the victims had to align
their beds every day as part of the ritual.

3232.60.text:
The physical removal of Spartans from the
rest of society, the barracks life of the

3238.77.text:
teenage boys and the barracks life of some
of the adults. A period of liminality as they

3244.86.text:
progress from one phase of their education
to the next. These are things we associate

3249.82.text:
with total institutions as well. The careful
management of what the outside world gets

3256.54.text:
to see as well is something that is very much
associated with total institutions as well.

3264.40.text:
Goffman makes a lot of the fact that in the
time of religious festivals, total institutions

3272.40.text:
will allow a moment of plenty and there is
also a very clear difference between what

3280.48.text:
the institution is like and what outsiders
get to see. The visitors room does not look

3286.61.text:
anything like what the room of an inmate will
actually be like. Visitors are never exposed

3292.39.text:
to the worst of the total institution. At
Sparta, the obvious time the visitors were

3297.55.text:
actually allowed in is festivals and it’s
a time when we know Sparta doesn’t look

3302.52.text:
anything like what it does at the rest of
the time and one of the obvious examples of

3306.75.text:
difference at the time of festivals in Sparta
is the food, which is much more opulent, much

3314.80.text:
more enjoyable fare than they have at the
rest of the time. And the other thing that

3319.95.text:
you associate with total institutions as well
is what sociologists call ‘secondary adjustments’;

3327.04.text:
ways of dodging the system and theft. The
message about theft that we get in Sparta

3332.61.text:
is very obvious, it comes in a variety of
sources and theft is something that is very

3337.47.text:
much part and parcel of modern military life.
You’re just not meant to get caught. In

3344.01.text:
basic training it is quite common for people
to ‘find’ objects that they’re going

3349.56.text:
to need – spare pairs of boots, extra shirts
that will be in pristine condition. As long

3355.41.text:
as no-one is caught finding them, it’s absolutely
fine. Equipment will also be stockpiled as

3361.81.text:
well. Non-commissioned officers will know
about it but the officers won’t, and if

3366.89.text:
the officers do find out about it, everyone
is punished quite severely. But as long as

3373.02.text:
you’re not caught, you will get away with
it. It’s exactly the same kind of rules

3377.15.text: that are going on in Sparta.

3379.09.text:
And if I may be allowed two extra minutes
I’d just like to finish on thinking about

3384.36.text:
what the psychological and physiological impact
of all of this might be. In Sparta, one of

3390.66.text:
the things that comes out of all of their
way in which their society works is a message

3394.95.text:
about cohesion. A society that is thinking
the same and acting the same and the obvious

3402.22.text:
example of that comes out in coordinated movement.
The marching of the Spartans into battle is

3408.01.text:
something that other Greeks admire; where
other Greeks will be known to run headlong

3413.51.text:
into battle, the Spartans march slowly and
synchronised into battle. It’s a kind of

3421.39.text:
process that is known today as ‘entrainment’.
Violence is also something that might be coming

3428.40.text:
out in the Spartan society as well. Cultural
spill over theory suggests that a society

3433.34.text:
which has violent activities such as the brutal
ball games the Spartans play, or the brutal

3439.15.text:
activities in the gymnasium, might generate
more violence in a society and violence within

3446.18.text:
it and outside it as well, and if you want
to see examples of Spartans being violent,

3452.06.text:
passages 27 and 28 you have a Spartan governor
in charge of the garrison in the recently

3460.70.text:
conquered Athens, the Spartan commander can’t
resist hitting an Athenian over the head with

3467.36.text:
his staff. Spartans are very good at beating
other people up with their sticks; it’s

3473.83.text:
what they seem to do. Passage 28 is an example
of the type of behaviour that happens when

3481.86.text:
Spartans get out of their society as well.
Pausanias, the victor at the battle of Plataea

3487.47.text:
is known for his violent behaviour to non-Spartans
once he’s out and about.

3494.39.text:
You’ve also got this potential death cult
developing in Sparta as well where the poetry

3498.85.text:
of Tyrtaeus is killing young men and there’s
a preponderance of leaders who go off and

3504.99.text:
fight to the death, losing battles because
they’re more interested in actually fighting

3509.88.text:
to the death and following the Spartan way,
than actually trying to win. You also see

3515.46.text:
Spartans struggling with the outside world.
Pausanias in passage 28, you have a strong

3520.76.text:
message about Spartans becoming greedy and
this is something that maps onto what sociologists

3528.09.text:
tell us about total institutions. When people
are released from a total institution they

3533.17.text:
either forget what things were like and actually
start to adapt too well to the outside world,

3538.97.text:
or they over-remember how awful it was and
then try and make up for it even more so.

3545.08.text:
There is also a strong message in our primary
sources of Spartans being angry. I’m compiling

3550.69.text:
a catalogue of Spartan behaviours and emotions
and one that comes out again and again is

3557.43.text:
anger. Spartans are very angry. They fly off
the handle at the drop of a hat. They are

3564.16.text:
also fearful. A very interesting work from
the 1930s catalogued all the examples of Spartans

3572.00.text:
being fearful. It suggested that this was
a national defect in Sparta, that they were

3577.22.text:
actually a naturally fearful people. I don’t
think that’s what’s going on here but

3582.32.text:
I think the brutality of the Spartan upbringing
is producing people who have somewhat a psychologically

3590.67.text:
damaged perspective and that brings me back
to the suggestion that the Spartans might

3595.84.text:
have suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder.
Rather than seeing the Spartans suffering

3600.66.text:
PTSD as a result of too much battle, I wonder
whether what’s actually going on in Sparta

3606.17.text:
is their upbringing is so brutal that it’s
actually creating problems for them and I’m

3611.89.text:
going to end by directing your attention to
passage 30 which is Plutarch’s description

3617.97.text:
of what happened to Pausanias, the Spartan
who’s already being violent to other people.

3625.55.text:
He decided he wanted a girl, his purpose was
to disgrace her, he insisted that she was

3633.12.text:
brought to his quarters, she came in when
he was not expecting it, she accidentally

3639.85.text:
knocked over the light. In blind panic he
stabbed her and the wording as Plutarch puts

3647.35.text:
it here is ‘he was fearing violence’.
Having killed the girl, he’s then plagued

3659.14.text:
by nightmares of her when she comes to see
him and harass him’ and he ends up having

3665.99.text:
a very unhappy experience. He goes to an oracle
of the dead to try and assuage his fears about

3674.50.text:
this and try and get to an end of the pollution
and she ends up prophesying that he will die

3681.33.text:
the hideous death that he ends up suffering.
Pausanias here bears many of the textbook

3689.51.text:
symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder.
He is hyper-vigilant, he is expecting disaster

3697.66.text:
at all occasions, he is plagued by bad dreams
from the events of his life. So I’m wondering

3704.39.text:
whether this is a symptom of potentially Spartans
being psychologically damaged by all of this

3710.46.text:
emphasis on the need to be obedient. And true
to form, I’ve finished five minutes over

3715.53.text:
which none of my students in the room would
be surprised by and that’s where I’ll
